answers.text: kinetic energy of a moving object

qas.question: In Newtonian physics, there is a universal law that says energy can be neither created nor what?
What law states, in part, that energy can change from one form to another?
What does uncommon energy forms include?
gravitational energy is stored by stretching what?
physical energy is released when what burns?
thermal energy gets carried by what?

plausible_answers.text: that energy can be neither created nor be destroyed

qas.question: What does the universal law say in Plutonium physics?

context: Common energy forms include the <a0_0><b3_0>kinetic energy<b3_0/> of a moving object<a0_0/>, the potential energy stored by an object's position in a force field (gravitational, electric or magnetic), the elastic energy stored by stretching <b4_0>solid objects<b4_0/>, the chemical energy released when a <b5_0>fuel<b5_0/> burns, the radiant energy carried by <b6_0>light<b6_0/>, and the thermal energy due to an object's temperature. All of the many forms of energy are convertible to other kinds of energy. In <a2_0>Newtonian physics<a2_0/>, there is a universal law of conservation of energy which says <b7_0>that energy can be neither created nor be <a1_0>destroyed<b7_0/><a1_0/>; however, it can change from one form to another.
